awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Exploratory research on the dynamics of convergence in interdisciplinary teams
awd_abstract_narration:
The Toolbox Dialogue Initiative (TDI) team proposes to conduct research on convergence which will help Growing Convergence Research (GCR) and other convergence-focused programs crystallize unique features of different types of convergence and provide more guidance to future awardees. TDI team will work directly with GCR awardees through project-focused Toolbox workshops to help them realize their convergence cultures. They will also make  the online resources curated by TDI available to all GCR awardees and more broadly to other individuals and teams conducting convergence research.

The project will include theoretical research designed to relate convergence to integration and cross-disciplinarity, and empirical research to identify different ways in which convergence is operationalized across funded projects. This research will connect the convergence literature more closely with the literature on integration and cross-disciplinarity, and it will also assist those pursuing convergence research in GCR, other NSF programs, and beyond to be more explicit in designing and delivering convergence.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The “Exploratory research on the dynamics of convergence in interdisciplinary teams” project (hereafter, “the project”) was designed to support the NSF Growing Convergence Research (GCR) Program from April 2021 through March 2024. Directed by the Toolbox Dialogue Initiative Center (TDIC) of Michigan State University, the project focused on enhancing the collaborative capacity of GCR teams awarded funding during that period. The NSF GCR program focuses on funding and supporting complex, crossdisciplinary teams to conduct convergence research that addresses challenges too large in scope and complexity to be addressed by any one discipline. 

The GCR program is a two-phase program, with Phase I covering years 1 and 2 and Phase II covering years 3-5. TDIC’s work takes place primarily in phase I. During phase I, TDIC delivered a series of workshops – one for each team of each GCR cohort. Workshops are 2 hours in length, beginning with a brief 20-minute presentation characterizing some of the challenges that convergence research teams face and how TDIC’s dialogical method can help participants overcome those challenges, followed by a 60-minute dialogue. The final step of the workshop is a co-creation activity in which teams are provided a model for thinking about the ways convergence will manifest in their specific projects. This model helps them think about the outputs/goals of the project, what inputs will be needed, and what integrative mechanisms will help turn those inputs into the convergent outputs they seek. Following the workshops, each team received a detailed booklet with content from the workshop as well as insights from the TDIC team. 

 

We also coordinated a webinar series comprising talks from invited speakers covering both conceptual and operational aspects of convergence. Each year, the webinar series began with a panel featuring Phase II awardees from previous cohorts called “Lessons from the Field: Perspectives on Catalyzing Convergence in GCR Phase II”. The GCR webinars are aimed at both current and future GCR awardees as well as other interested parties within NSF and beyond. Recordings of these webinars are posted at the GCR site (https://new.nsf.gov/od/oia/ia/growing-convergence-research-nsf). 

Our project also included a research component, focused on convergence as a concept as well as how GCR awardees operationalized that concept in their work. Our work on convergence as a concept yielded a white paper that we presented to the GCR coordinating committee. This paper detailed some of the history of convergence as well as its theoretical underpinnings. We also developed and conducted a series of interviews and a survey for convergence teams. The data from the interviews and survey help us understand how teams in the GCR program conceive of convergence and the myriad ways in which they facilitate it in their projects. 

 

The project advanced scientific knowledge in three ways. First, it expanded the awareness GCR awardees have of the importance of collaborative process in the conduct of convergence research. Second, it provided TDIC with the opportunity to make the Toolbox dialogue method, a workshop-based method that enhances communication and collaboration in crossdisciplinary research projects, more broadly available to complex research teams. Third, it enabled TDIC to conduct both theoretical and empirical research that will further expand our understanding of convergence research as well as how best to support and facilitate it.

The project also had a number of broader impacts. First, by focusing on the facilitation of process, it helped the GCR projects pursue their own broader impacts by demonstrating the value of dialogue and the collaborative process in scientific research. Second, it provided the leaders of the teams with insights regarding their team members, the collaborative climate of their team, and crossdisciplinary processes they could use to enhance the capacity of their teams to collaborate successfully. Third, it helped TDIC expand its infrastructure and develop its method, which helped it contribute to other projects nationally and internationally. Finally, the project provided an opportunity to pilot theoretical and empirical research on convergence, through which graduate students gained professional development.
